00002   <caption>options</caption>
00003   <tr>
00004     <th>Statement</th>
00005     <th>Description</th>
00006   </tr>
00007   <tr>
00008     <td>set timeout</td>
00009     <td>
00010       <table>
00011         <tr>
00012           <td class="key">interval</td>
00013           <td>Interval between purging expired states and fragments.</td>
00014         </tr>
00015         <tr>
00016           <td class="key">frag</td>
00017           <td>Seconds before an unassembled fragment is expired.</td>
00018         </tr>
00019         <tr>
00020           <td class="key">src.track</td>
00021           <td>Length of time to retain a source tracking entry after
00022               the last state expires.</td>
00023         </tr>
00024       </table>
00025     </td>
00026   </tr>
00027   <tr>
00028     <td colspan="2">
00029       <p>When a packet matches a stateful connection, the seconds to live
00030          for the connection will be updated to that of the proto.modifier
00031          which corresponds to the connection state.  Each packet which
00032          matches this state will reset the TTL.  Tuning these values may 
00033          improve the performance of the firewall at the risk of dropping valid
00034          idle connections.</p>
00035     </td>
00036   </tr>
00037   <tr>
00038     <td colspan="2">
00039       <table>
00040         <tr>
00041           <td class="key">tcp.first</td>
00042           <td>The state after the first packet.</td>
00043         </tr>
00044         <tr>
00045           <td class="key">tcp.opening</td>
00046           <td>The state before the destination host ever sends a packet.</td>
00047         </tr>
00048         <tr>
00049           <td class="key">tcp.established</td>
00050           <td>The fully established state.</td>
00051         </tr>
00052         <tr>
00053           <td class="key">tcp.closing</td>
00054           <td>The state after the first FIN has been sent.</td>
00055         </tr>
00056         <tr>
00057           <td class="key">tcp.finwait</td>
00058           <td>The state after both FINs have been exchanged and the connection 
00059               is closed.  Some hosts (notably web servers on Solaris)
00060               send TCP packets even after closing the connection.  Increasing 
00061               tcp.finwait (and possibly tcp.closing) can prevent blocking 
00062               of such packets.</td>
00063         </tr>
00064         <tr>
00065           <td class="key">tcp.closed</td>
00066           <td>The state after one endpoint sends an RST.</td>
00067         </tr>
00068       </table>
00069     </td>
00070   </tr>
00071   <tr>
00072     <td colspan="2">
00073       <p>ICMP and UDP are handled in a fashion similar to TCP, but with a
00074           much more limited set of states:</p>
00075 
00076       <table>
00077         <tr>
00078           <td class="key">udp.first</td>
00079           <td>The state after the first packet.</td>
00080         </tr>
00081         <tr>
00082           <td class="key">udp.single</td>
00083           <td>The state if the source host sends more than one packet but
00084               the destination host has never sent one back.</td>
00085         </tr>
00086         <tr>
00087           <td class="key">udp.multiple</td>
00088           <td>The state if both hosts have sent packets.</td>
00089         </tr>
00090         <tr>
00091           <td class="key">icmp.first</td>
00092           <td>The state after the first packet.</td>
00093         </tr>
00094         <tr>
00095           <td class="key">icmp.error</td>
00096           <td>The state after an ICMP error came back in response to an
00097               ICMP packet.</td>
00098         </tr>
00099       </table>
00100     </td>
00101   </tr>
00102   <tr>
00103     <td colspan="2">
00104       <p>Other protocols are handled similarly to UDP:</p>
00105       <p>other.first<br />
00106        other.single<br />
00107        other.multiple</p>
00108     </td>
00109   </tr>
00110   <tr>
00111     <td colspan="2">
00112       <p>Timeout values can be reduced adaptively as the number of state
00113          table entries grows.</p>
00114       <table>
00115         <tr>
00116           <td class="key">adaptive.start</td>
00117           <td>When the number of state entries exceeds this value, adaptive
00118               scaling begins.  All timeout values are scaled linearly with
00119               factor (adaptive.end - number of states) / (adaptive.end -
00120               adaptive.start).</td>
00121         </tr>
00122         <tr>
00123           <td class="key">adaptive.end</td>
00124           <td>When reaching this number of state entries, all timeout values 
00125               become zero, effectively purging all state entries immediately.
00126               This value is used to define the scale factor, it should not 
00127               actually be reached (set a lower state limit, see below).</td>
00128         </tr>
00129       </table>
00130     </td>
00131   </tr>
00132   <tr>
00133     <td colspan="2">
00134       <p>These values can be defined both globally and for each rule.  When
00135          used on a per-rule basis, the values relate to the number of states
00136          created by the rule, otherwise to the total number of states.</p>
00137 
00138       <p>For example:</p>
00139 <pre>
00140 set timeout tcp.first 120
00141 set timeout tcp.established 86400
00142 set timeout { adaptive.start 6000, adaptive.end 12000 }
00143 set limit states 10000
00144 </pre>
00145 
00146       <p>With 9000 state table entries, the timeout values are scaled to 50%>
00147        (tcp.first 60, tcp.established 43200).</p>
00148     </td>
00149   </tr>
00150   <tr>
00151     <td nowrap="nowrap">set loginterface</td>
00152     <td>
00153       <p>Enable collection of packet and byte count statistics for the given
00154          interface.  These statistics can be viewed using</p>
00155 
00156         <code># pfctl -s info</code>
00157 
00158       <p>In this example pf(4) collects statistics on the interface named
00159          dc0:</p>
00160 
00161         <code>set loginterface dc0</code>
00162 
00163       <p>One can disable the loginterface using:</p>
00164 
00165         <code>set loginterface none</code>
00166     </td>
00167   </tr>
00168   <tr>
00169     <td nowrap="nowrap">set limit</td>
00170     <td>
00171       <p>Sets hard limits on the memory pools used by the packet filter.
00172          See pool(9) for an explanation of memory pools.</p>
00173 
00174       <p>For example,</p>
00175 
00176         <code>set limit states 20000</code>
00177 
00178       <p>sets the maximum number of entries in the memory pool used by state
00179          table entries (generated by keep state rules) to 20000.  Using</p>
00180 
00181         <code>set limit frags 20000</code>
00182 
00183       <p>sets the maximum number of entries in the memory pool used for
00184          fragment reassembly (generated by scrub rules) to 20000.  Finally,</p>
00185 
00186         <code>set limit src-nodes 2000</code>
00187 
00188       <p>sets the maximum number of entries in the memory pool used for
00189          tracking source IP addresses (generated by the sticky-address and
00190          source-track options) to 2000.</p>
00191 
00192       <p>These can be combined:</p>
00193 
00194         <code>set limit { states 20000, frags 20000, src-nodes 2000 }</code>
00195     </td>
00196   </tr>
00197   <tr>
00198     <td nowrap="nowrap">set optimization</td>
00199     <td>
00200       <p>Optimize the engine for one of the following network environments:</p>
00201 
00202       <table>
00203         <tr>
00204           <td class="key">normal</td>
00205           <td>A normal network environment.  Suitable for almost all networks.</td>
00206         </tr>
00207         <tr>
00208           <td class="key">high-latency</td>
00209           <td>A high-latency environment (such as a satellite connection).</td>
00210         </tr>
00211         <tr>
00212           <td class="key">satellite</td>
00213           <td>Alias for high-latency.</td>
00214         </tr>
00215         <tr>
00216           <td class="key">aggressive</td>
00217           <td>Aggressively expire connections.  This can greatly reduce the
00218               memory usage of the firewall at the cost of dropping idle
00219               connections early.<td>
00220         </tr>
00221         <tr>
00222           <td class="key">conservative</td>
00223           <td>Extremely conservative settings.  Avoid dropping legitimate
00224               connections at the expense of greater memory utilization
00225               (possibly much greater on a busy network) and slightly 
00226               increased processor utilization.</td>
00227         </tr>
00228       </table>
00229     </td>
00230   </tr>
00231   <tr>
00232     <td nowrap="nowrap">set block-policy</td>
00233     <td>
00234       <p>The block-policy option sets the default behaviour for the packet
00235          block action:</p>
00236       
00237       <table>
00238         <tr>
00239           <td class="key">drop</td>
00240           <td>Packet is silently dropped.</td>
00241         </tr>
00242         <tr>
00243           <td class="key">return</td>
00244           <td>A TCP RST is returned for blocked TCP packets, an ICMP
00245               UNREACHABLE is returned for blocked UDP packets, and all
00246               other packets are silently dropped.</td>
00247         </tr>
00248       </table>
00249     </td>
00250   </tr>
00251   <tr>
00252     <td nowrap="nowrap">set state-policy</td>
00253     <td>
00254       <p>The state-policy option sets the default behaviour for states:</p>
00255       
00256       <table>
00257         <tr>
00258           <td class="key">if-bound</td>
00259           <td>States are bound to interface.</td>
00260         </tr>
00261         <tr>
00262           <td class="key">group-bound</td>
00263           <td>States are bound to interface group (i.e. ppp)</td>
00264         </tr>
00265         <tr>
00266           <td class="key">floating</td>
00267           <td>States can match packets on any interfaces (the default).</td>
00268         </tr>
00269       </table>
00270     </td>
00271   </tr>
00272 
00273   <tr>
00274     <td nowrap="nowrap">set require-order</td>
00275     <td>By default pfctl(8) enforces an ordering of the statement types in
00276         the ruleset to: options, normalization, queueing, translation,
00277         filtering.  Setting this option to no disables this enforcement.
00278         There may be non-trivial and non-obvious implications to an out of
00279         order ruleset.  Consider carefully before disabling the order enforcement.
00280     </td>
00281   </tr>
00282   <tr>
00283     <td nowrap="nowrap">set fingerprints</td>
00284     <td>Load fingerprints of known operating systems from the given filename.  
00285        By default fingerprints of known operating systems are automatically 
00286        loaded from pf.os(5) in /etc but can be overridden via
00287        this option.  Setting this option may leave a small period of time
00288        where the fingerprints referenced by the currently active ruleset
00289        are inconsistent until the new ruleset finishes loading.
00290     </td>
00291   </tr>
00292   <tr>
00293     <td nowrap="nowrap">set debug</td>
00294     <td>
00295       <p>Set the debug level to one of the following:</p>
00296       
00297       <table>
00298         <tr>
00299           <td class="key">none</td>
00300           <td>Don't generate debug messages.</td>
00301         </tr>
00302         <tr>
00303           <td class="key">urgent</td>
00304           <td>Generate debug messages only for serious errors.</td>
00305         </tr>
00306         <tr>
00307           <td class="key">misc</td>
00308           <td>Generate debug messages for various errors.</td>
00309         </tr>
00310         <tr>
00311           <td class="key">loud</td>
00312           <td>Generate debug messages for common conditions.</td>
00313         </tr>
00314       </table>
00315     </td>
00316   </tr>
00317 </table>
